required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of the Sugar Sucrose on Bodyweight and Energy Intake Over 28 Days in Obese Women
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of the Sugar Sucrose on Bodyweight and Energy Intake Over 28 Days in Obese Women

brief_summary.textblock: This study partially replicates two previous studies with normal weight women, and overweight women. Both found that women could compensate for sucrose added to the diet in carbonated soft drinks (4 x250ml total1800 kJ per day) when it was given blind over a period of 4 weeks. The hypothesis is that this applies also to obese women, who will not gain weight, increase overall energy intake in the diet, or eat differently whilst consuming sucrose. 42 participants shall be randomly assigned to either be given carbonated drinks that contain sucrose, or drinks that are artificially sweetened.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Basic Science

primary_outcome.measure: Change in body weight from baseline

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean daily dietary intake estimated from unweighed food diaries

other_outcome.description: Mood was assessed 4 times per day over the study period

intervention.description: Sucrose in carbonated soft drinks (4 x250ml total1800 kJ per day)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female
- BMI 30-35 kg/mÂ²
- at least one period of dietary restriction of 4 weeks or more in the last 24 months
Exclusion Criteria:
- dislike of popular sweet carbonated drinks
- dieting during the last month
- history of diabetes
- having an eating disorder
- depression,
- being a smoker
- pregnant
- lactating,
- wearing a pacemaker
- currently taking medication for mood or thyroid disorders
